eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Post cesarean delivery (combined vaginal/cesarean deliveries are not eligible)
* Singleton, twin or triplet gestation

Exclusion Criteria:

* An opioid prescription filled during the current pregnancy
* Known history of opioid use disorder, by medical record review
* Contraindication to opioids (oxycodone)
* Contraindications to both acetaminophen and ibuprofen
* Significant surgical procedures (e.g., hysterectomy) prior to randomization as pain trajectory will be completely different
* Fetal or neonatal death prior to randomization
* Inability to randomize within 1 day before planned discharge from the hospital
* Inability to participate in shared decision making as assessed by research staff
* Language barrier (non-English or Spanish speaking)
* Participation in this trial in a previous pregnancy
* Participation in another intervention study that influences the primary outcome in this trial

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants With Worst Pain Score of Moderate to Severe on the Brief Pain Inventory
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of participants with moderate to severe pain at 1 week post-discharge; moderate to severe pain is defined as a value of 4 or higher on the "Worst Pain" question of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) in the last 24 hours. The BPI measures pain severity on a numeric scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the highest level of pain.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants Who Filled One or More Opioid Prescriptions Beyond the Amount Prescribed at Discharge
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of participants who filled one or more opioid prescriptions beyond what was prescribed to them at discharge - measured at ninety days postpartum

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Opioid Prescriptions Filled
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of opioid prescriptions filled by ninety days postpartum

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Opioid Tablets Unused Since Discharge
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of opioid tablets unused from discharge to 90 days postpartum

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Morphine Milligram Equivalents Used at 2 Weeks Post Discharge
outcomeMeasures.description: Total morphine milligram equivalents (MME) used from discharge to 2 weeks post-discharge. MME is the amount of milligrams of morphine an opioid dose is equal to when prescribed. Calculating MME accounts for differences in opioid drug type and strength.

outcomeMeasures.title: Worst Pain Severity Score at 2 Weeks Post Discharge
outcomeMeasures.description: Pain severity scores assessed on the Brief Pain Inventory numeric scale from 0 to 10 at 2 weeks post-discharge. The BPI measures pain severity on a numeric scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the highest level of pain.

outcomeMeasures.title: Pain Interference Score ≥ 4 at 2 Weeks Post Discharge
outcomeMeasures.description: Pain interference scores ≥ 4 on the Brief Pain Inventory (numeric scale from 0 to 10) at 2 weeks post-discharge. The BPI measures pain severity on a numeric scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the highest level of pain. This outcome asks participants to indicate their pain scores for the week prior to completing the inventory.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Participants Who Indicated an Improved Global Impression of Change
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of participants who indicated an improved global impression of change in overall pain at 2 weeks post-discharge. This represents a selection on a multiple choice survey question with the response options: very much improved, much improved, minimally improved, no change, minimally worse, much worse, very much worse.

outcomeMeasures.title: Infant Hospital Readmissions
outcomeMeasures.description: Proportion of infants readmitted to the hospital

outcomeMeasures.title: Maternal Depression Score ≥ 13
outcomeMeasures.description: The proportion of participants with a score of 13 or higher on the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale. The minimum score is 0 and the maximum score is 30. Higher scores indicate worse outcomes, where persons scoring about 13 are likely to be suffering from a depressive illness. The scale indicates how the respondent has felt during the previous week.
